Silk Protein Moisturizer: Follow up with a silk protein-infused moisturizer to lock in moisture and protect the skin throughout the day or night. Choose a moisturiser with a luxurious texture that leaves your skin soft, smooth, and supple.
-
Silk Protein Mask: Apply a silk protein mask to your skin once or twice a week for extra hydration and nourishment. Silk protein masks replenish the skin's moisture barrier, promoting a more radiant and youthful appearance.
-
Targeted Treatments: To address specific concerns in these areas, consider using silk protein-containing eye creams or neck creams. Silk proteins can help reduce the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles, and sagging skin, making the delicate eye and neck areas appear smoother and firmer.
-

Sensitive Skin: A gentle cream cleanser enriched with silk proteins can soothe and comfort sensitive skin while effectively removing impurities. Look for fragrance-free formulas with calming ingredients like chamomile or aloe vera. Choose a serum specifically formulated for sensitive skin, containing silk proteins and soothing ingredients such as centella asiatica or green tea extract to reduce redness and inflammation. Choose a nourishing barrier cream enriched with silk proteins and ceramides to boost the skin's natural protective barrier and prevent moisture loss.
-

The future of silk in skincare looks promising, with exciting developments on the horizon. Silk is poised to play an increasingly important role in the skincare industry, offering natural and effective solutions for healthy, radiant skin. This includes innovative formulations, sustainable sourcing, advanced delivery systems, and biotechnological advancement.

Silk Protein Body Scrub: Ingredients are 1/2 cup sugar or salt (exfoliating), 2 tablespoons coconut oil or olive oil (moisturizing), 1 tablespoon silk protein powder (nourishing and softening) and 5-10 drops of your favorite essential oil for fragrance (optional). In a small bowl, mix the sugar or salt, coconut oil or olive oil, silk protein powder, and essential oil (if using) until well combined. Apply the scrub to damp skin, massaging in gentle circular motions to exfoliate and moisturize. Pay special attention to rough areas like elbows, knees, and heels. Rinse off with warm water, then pat your skin dry and follow up with a moisturizer for extra hydration.
Beyond Hydration: The Multifaceted Benefits of Silk Proteins

Choosing the best silk protein products for your skin type involves considering your skin's specific needs and preferences. Here are some recommendations for silk protein products tailored to different skin types:
-
Dry Skin: A hydrating cleanser enriched with silk proteins can effectively cleanse the skin while retaining moisture. Look for creamy formulas that will leave your skin feeling soft and nourished. A serum enriched with silk proteins and hydrating ingredients such as hyaluronic acid can replenish dry skin and increase overall hydration. To deeply hydrate and soften dry skin, choose a luxurious moisturiser enriched with silk proteins and emollients like shea butter and jojoba oil.

Silk proteins have remarkable properties that help to keep the skin youthful and combat signs of ageing. Silk proteins perform anti-aging functions such as moisture retention, collagen production, antioxidant protection, repair and regeneration, soothing, softness and smoothness, and protection against environmental damage. Incorporating silk protein-infused skincare products into your daily routine can help keep your skin youthful and combat visible signs of ageing. Silk proteins provide antioxidant protection, soothe inflammation, and improve hydration, making them an all-around anti-aging skincare solution.
Healing and Repair: Silk's Role in Strengthening the Skin Barrier
Silk plays a significant role in strengthening the skin barrier, contributing to its healing and repair processes. Here's how silk aids in fortifying the skin barrier:
-

Normal/Combination Skin: A foaming cleanser containing silk proteins can effectively cleanse normal or combination skin without leaving a residue. Look for formulas that balance oil production and maintain the skin's natural pH. Choose a lightweight hydrating serum with silk proteins and humectants like glycerin or hyaluronic acid to provide balanced hydration and improve skin texture. Look for a lightweight day cream infused with silk proteins and antioxidants like vitamin E or green tea extract to protect the skin from environmental damage and maintain moisture balance throughout the day.

Sericin is a sticky, gummy protein that coats the outer layer of silk fibres, also known as silk gum. It is produced by the silkworm's silk gland alongside fibroin during the silk-spinning process.
-
Sericin serves as a protective layer for the delicate fibroin fibres, shielding them from environmental damage and predators as the silkworm develops. It also contributes to the structural integrity of the silk cocoon.
-
Sericin is water soluble and has adhesive properties, making it useful in a variety of applications, including textiles, cosmetics, and biomedical materials. It has moisturizing and film-forming properties, which help hydrate and protect the skin.
-
Sericin has been shown to have antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and wound-healing properties, which make it useful for skincare. It soothes and calms irritated skin, increases collagen production, and improves elasticity and firmness.

Silk Protein Hair Treatment: Ingredients are 2 tablespoons coconut oil (conditioning and moisturizing), 1 tablespoon silk protein powder (strengthens and nourishes hair) and 5-10 drops of your favorite essential oil for fragrance (optional). In a microwave-safe bowl, melt the coconut oil until it is liquid but not hot. Stir in the silk protein powder and essential oil (if using) until well combined. Apply the mixture to damp hair, focusing on the ends and any areas that are dry or damaged. Cover your hair with a shower cap or towel and leave the treatment on for at least 30 minutes, or overnight for deeper conditioning. Rinse out the treatment with warm water, then shampoo and condition your hair as usual.
-

Silk proteins are naturally soothing and anti-inflammatory, which help to calm and comfort the skin. They reduce redness, irritation, and inflammation, which can impair the skin's barrier function. By soothing the skin, silk proteins support its ability to repair and strengthen the barrier.
-
The skin barrier is constantly exposed to environmental stressors such as UV radiation, pollution, and extreme weather, which can weaken its structure. Silk proteins form a protective barrier on the skin's surface, shielding it from external factors and preventing damage. This protection enables the skin barrier to perform optimally while maintaining its strength and integrity.

Synthetic Peptides: Synthetic peptides are created in a laboratory setting and can be produced in larger quantities at a lower cost. They are widely used in a variety of skincare products, including mass-market and luxury brands.
Integrating Silk Proteins into Your Skincare Regimen

Silk Proteins vs. Synthetic Peptides: A Comparative Insight
Silk proteins and synthetic peptides are both popular skincare ingredients, with each providing unique skin benefits. Here's a comparison of silk proteins and synthetic peptides:

Synthetic Peptides: Chemical synthesis methods are employed in a laboratory setting to artificially create synthetic peptides. They are made to resemble peptides that are present in the skin naturally.

Choose Silk Protein-Infused Products: Look for skincare products that include silk proteins as a main ingredient. These could consist of masks, treatments, moisturisers, serums, and cleansers. To ensure that silk proteins are present and, for maximum effectiveness, listed higher up in the ingredient list, carefully read the product labels' ingredient lists.

Silk Protein Cleanser: To gently cleanse your skin and provide hydrating and nourishing benefits, begin your skincare routine with a cleanser infused with silk protein. Select a mild formula free of sulphates that will not deplete the skin's natural oils.
-
Silk Protein Serum: Use a silk protein serum as part of your skincare regimen to provide skin with intense hydration and nourishment. Serums are great for targeting particular skin concerns like dryness, dullness, or fine lines because they are lightweight and easily absorbed.

Synthetic Peptides: Synthetic peptides target specific skin concerns using unique amino acid sequences. Depending on their structure and function, various peptides can stimulate collagen synthesis, improve skin elasticity, reduce wrinkles, or increase hydration.

Silk proteins: Most people can tolerate silk proteins well, and they are biocompatible with human skin. They work well on all skin types, even the most delicate and sensitive ones, and are hypoallergenic.

Synthetic Peptides: Depending on their chemical structure and formulation, synthetic peptides can have varying degrees of biocompatibility. In some people, some peptides can irritate or cause sensitivity, especially when used in high concentrations or combination with other active ingredients.

Experiment with various products and formulations to see what works best for your skin type and concerns, and then enjoy the luxurious feel and benefits of silk-infused skincare.
The Best Silk Protein Products for Every Skin Type

To extract silk proteins, the cocoons are typically boiled in water to soften the sericin, a sticky protein that coats the fibers. This process, known as degumming, aids in the dissolution and separation of sericin from fibroin, the structural protein that forms the bulk of the silk fiber.
-
Following degumming, the softened cocoons are unwound or reeled to extract the silk filaments. The silk fibers are carefully unravelled from the cocoons and wound onto spools or reels.
-
Once extracted, the silk filaments are dried and processed to remove any remaining impurities and sericin. This could include washing, bleaching, and refining the silk fibres to create a purified silk protein extract suitable for use in skincare products.

Silk proteins have numerous benefits besides hydration, making them a versatile and valuable ingredient in skincare and hair care products. Silk proteins provide a variety of benefits, including moisturization, nourishment, repair and regeneration, smoothness and softness, antioxidant protection, anti-inflammatory properties, gentleness and compatibility, and improved active ingredient delivery. Silk proteins can help you achieve healthier, more radiant skin and hair by hydrating, nourishing, repairing, and protecting them.
Anti-Aging Marvel: How Silk Proteins Preserve Skin's Youthfulness

Silk proteins have excellent moisture-retaining properties and form a protective film on the skin's surface to help prevent water loss. By maintaining optimal hydration levels, silk supports the skin barrier's function, ensuring it remains intact and effective in retaining moisture.

The skin's natural barrier function is strengthened in part by silk proteins. They help protect the skin from outside aggressors like pollutants, irritants, and pathogens by forming a physical barrier on its surface. By keeping dangerous chemicals from damaging the skin, this barrier promotes the general health of the skin.
-
Silk proteins have regenerative properties, which help to repair and rejuvenate the skin barrier. They increase cell turnover and promote the synthesis of collagen and elastin fibres, which are critical components of the skin's structure. This repair process helps to restore the skin barrier's integrity, making it more resilient and damage-resistant.

Silk proteins are biocompatible with human skin, which means they are well tolerated and readily absorbed. They blend in with the skin's natural lipid barrier, increasing its strength and resilience without causing irritation or allergic reactions. Silk's compatibility makes it an ideal ingredient for strengthening the skin barrier.
A Glow Like No Other: Real Results from Silk Protein Usage
Silk protein can give you a glow like no other because of its numerous skin-beneficial properties. Hydration and moisture balance, improved skin texture, increased elasticity and firmness, reduction in fine lines and wrinkles, soothing and calming effect, a brighter, more radiant complexion, and protection against environmental damage are some of the real benefits of using silk protein products in your skincare routine.
Embracing Nature's Gift: The Future of Silk in Skincare

Fibroin is the structural protein that makes up the majority of silk fibres. It is produced by the silkworm's silk gland and consists of long, fibrous chains of amino acids organised in a complex structure.
-
Fibroin adds strength, resilience, and flexibility to silk fibres, giving them a smooth and lustrous appearance. It forms the core of the silk filament and is responsible for silk's remarkable mechanical properties.
-
Fibroin is insoluble in water and resistant to heat, chemicals, and ultraviolet radiation. It has high tensile strength, elasticity, and biocompatibility, making it an excellent choice for a variety of applications such as textiles, biomaterials, and medical devices.
-

Fibroin is valued for its skin-rejuvenating properties, which improve skin hydration, elasticity, and texture. It creates a protective barrier on the skin's surface to prevent moisture loss and environmental damage. Fibroin-based skincare products promote collagen synthesis, reduce wrinkles, and enhance the overall health and appearance of the skin.

Plus, because silk is less absorbent than either cotton or linen, your hair is likely to remain better hydrated, too.
You can make the most of silk’s benefits by sleeping on silk pillowcases. Alternatively, wrap your hair overnight with a silk bonnet or scarf in order to experience similar benefits.
How To Boost Your Hair With Silk Protein
Sleep on silk
Sleeping on silk pillowcases or with a silk bonnet can help your hair to retain its moisture and reduce potential tangles caused by tossing and turning against cotton or linen pillowcases.
Use haircare products with added silk proteins
The benefits of silk proteins are being increasingly recognized by the haircare industry, meaning that there are plenty of products to choose from that have had hydrolyzed silk protein added to them.
Look for shampoos and conditioners, as well as treatments like masques and leave-in conditioners for extra nourishment.
DIY haircare

In fact, silk has so many benefits that it’s been used across Asia for a number of centuries.
Silk protein itself is made up of two proteins – fibrous protein fibroin and sticky protein sericin.
You don’t need to know the specifics of these proteins and how they benefit hair – but it’s this unique structure that makes silk protein so beneficial for hair.
Silk protein is often added to haircare products in order to benefit hair. In its original form, silk protein comes as a shell-like structure (that’s what the silkworms spin).
As such, it has to be broken down so as to be suitable for inclusion in haircare products.
This is done via the process of hydrolysis, which essentially means that the silk protein has been broken down by water.
That’s why any silk protein added to haircare products is typically identified as hydrolyzed silk protein.
How Does Silk Protein Improve Hair Health?

As such, it helps to restore and repair hair from within and therefore has a protective function.
3. Helps repair damage
Including hydrolyzed silk protein in your hair can also help to repair damage by rebuilding broken bonds and sealing and smoothing down cuticles.
As such, it can help to reduce the damaging effects of excessive chemical or heat exposure.
Whilst it won’t help hair grow, ensuring that your hair is in the healthiest possible condition is a great way of supporting hair growth and minimizing loss or shedding.
4. Reduces dryness and boosts moisture
Silk proteins are known for being moisture retentive, meaning that they help to lock hydration into hair and prevent loss of moisture from strands.
Hydrated hair is healthy hair, and will contribute to overall hair strength and elasticity.
It will also mean that hair is less prone to frizz and split ends, therefore reducing any hair shedding, loss or breakage.

Cysteine is also the main amino acid from which keratin is made. As such, cysteine is the main amino acid found in your hair, skin, and nails – and it also contributes to the production of collagen.
It’s specifically because hydrolyzed silk protein contains cysteine that it’s so beneficial for hair.
By supporting, reinforcing, and adding the amino acid cysteine to your hair, hydrolyzed silk protein helps to support the keratin levels in the hair, moisturizing and strengthening hair from within.
Over time, as hydrolyzed protein helps to improve hair’s overall health, it will also improve hair’s shine and elasticity, reducing the risk of breakage.
8 Benefits Of Silk Protein For Hair
1. Boosts The strength of hair
When hair is damaged through frequent exposure to either heat or chemical treatments, the hair’s cuticle will lift up.
It’s this lifting action that weakens hair’s overall structure and strength.

In fact, it’s because silk proteins won’t sap your hair of vital moisture that silk pillowcases are so popular.
If you regularly use hair oils and other treatments on parched strands, silk pillowcases won’t draw these hydrating treatments away, helping them to do their best work.
5. Improves hair’s softness and texture
Silk is notoriously very soft – we don’t describe things as ‘silky’ for no reason!
As already mentioned, many standard haircare procedures can cause the hair’s cuticle to lift, which will make your hair’s texture rough, as well as make hair more likely to tangle or frizz.
Silk proteins penetrate the hair shaft, which helps to smooth the cuticle down. This results in softer, sleeker hair that’s also overall more manageable.
6. Better manageability
When your hair is softer and stronger, it’s going to be more manageable overall. Hydrolyzed silk protein can reduce the porosity of the hair, which helps to tame unruly locks.

Protein is the building block of hair and silk protein, therefore, can be a wise investment into your haircare routine. In this article, I go through 8 of the most common benefits of using silk protein for hair.
Silk protein has innumerable benefits for hair such as boosting moisture levels to improving overall elasticity, strength, and shine. Incorporating haircare products containing hydrolyzed silk protein into your routine can really benefit your strands.
What Is Silk Protein?
Silk has become something of a ‘must have’ for today’s beauty aficionados – and for good reason. But what actually is silk protein?
Silk is made by silkworms, and the most premium kind is mulberry silk, which comes from silkworms that subsist exclusively on a diet of mulberry trees.
As well as being famously soft and silky to the touch, silk is also hypoallergenic, moisture retentive, and resists wrinkling far better than other fabrics like cotton or linen.

Plus, you’re less likely to experience frizz, tangles, and knots with sleek, hydrated hair, which will save you overall time and effort.
7. Helps with hair color
If you’re a fan of coloring your hair, using shampoos and conditioners containing hydrolyzed silk protein is a great way of keeping your color for longer.
Exposure to environmental hazards – particularly the sun’s UV rays – can diminish the vibrancy of your new color.
Integrating products with hydrolyzed silk protein into your haircare routine can help to reduce these effects (as well as contribute to the overall health of colored hair).
8. Reduces friction
Using haircare products enriched with hydrolyzed silk proteins is one way to boost your hair, but you can also sleep on silk in order to benefit from this wonder material.
Because silk is so soft, when you sleep on it, you reduce any friction that may occur between the pillow and your hair.
You’re therefore less likely to experience frizz and tangles when you wake up.

Hydrolyzed silk protein can typically be purchased in two forms either a liquid or powder. These can then be added to your regular haircare products.
You could even make up a liquid solution and add it to a spray bottle for regular misting over your hair.
Just be sure to keep any DIY mixture containing hydrolyzed silk protein in the fridge. It’s also wise to avoid a concentration level of over 10%.
Excessive amounts of protein in the hair will make your strands brittle and unworkable.
Concentrations between 0.5 and 10% should be more than enough, and it’s probably wise to start on the lower spectrum and build up more as your hair gets used to the silk protein.
Can I Use Silk Protein On My Hair Everyday?
If you use protein treatments on your hair on a daily basis, your strands are likely to become very brittle and stiff.
It’s best to space out the use of hydrolyzed silk protein and only use very intensive treatments once a month so as to avoid protein buildup.

When your hair’s strength and structure are compromised, you’ll also be sacrificing its elasticity and resilience, and will consequently be more likely to experience split ends and breakage.
Using hydrolyzed silk protein in your hair can help to repair these broken bonds and smooth the cuticle back down.
It, therefore, adds a layer of protection as it penetrates the hair, improving overall tensile strength and elasticity without weighing hair down.
However, don’t stop using your heat protection spray when you’re straightening or blow-drying your hair.
Integrating hydrolyzed silk protein into your haircare will restore and rejuvenate struggling strands, but you should nonetheless continue to take protective measures.
2. Penetrates hair shaft and coats fibers
Because silk protein is hydrolyzed when it is added to haircare products, it has a low molecular weight.
This means that it’s better at penetrating and absorbing into the hair shaft, rather than simply sitting on it.

Between the use of heated styling tools like flat irons and curlers through to chemical treatments and the regular use of bleach, we can be really hard on our hair.
Unhealthy hair is typically dehydrated and dull, prone to breakage and frizz, and generally lacking any strength.
Now, hair is predominantly made up of the protein keratin and it helps to build and repair all aspects of your hair.
Whilst keratin is less vulnerable to damage than other cells in your body, excessive exposure to heat and chemicals will weaken the keratin, resulting in dry, lackluster hair.
Keratin, therefore, needs the support of other proteins and amino acids in order to contribute to and maintain hair’s overall strength and structure.
And this is where hydrolyzed silk comes in.
Hydrolyzed silk protein contains cysteine, which is an amino acid that’s important in the creation of protein in the body.

The current scale of manufacturing for lavender oil-infused textiles is growing rapidly, with the global market for lavender oil expected to reach around USD 1201 Million by 2030 with a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of roughly 5.0%. This is driven by the increasing demand for natural and sustainable products in the beauty, wellness, and home care industries.

However, there are challenges in scaling up production to meet market demand. One of the main challenges is the cultivation of lavender crops. According to a study on current trends for Lavender crops and products, there are several challenges in cultivating Lavandula angustifolia Mill., including weed control, pests and diseases, and proper pruning techniques. These challenges can affect the quality and quantity of the lavender oil produced, which in turn impacts the availability of raw materials for textile production.

To address these challenges, biotechnology has been introduced to the production of lavender oil-infused textiles. This includes the use of silk-based microcapsules to encapsulate the lavender oil, providing durability and retaining its repellent properties even after 40 washes. A systematic review of studies on textiles as a potential carrier for the therapeutic effects of essential oils found that this approach is effective in delivering aromatic compounds and has minimal environmental impact.

The development of lavender oil-infused textiles not only advances the technology in mosquito protection, but also offers a sustainable alternative to traditional repellents like DEET and permethrin. This is important as these chemicals have been linked to health concerns, making natural solutions like lavender oil a preferred choice for consumers.

Incorporating this technology into everyday consumer items can have a significant impact on public health, especially in areas where mosquito-borne diseases are prevalent. It also presents an intersection of biotechnology and traditional plant-based solutions, showcasing the potential for innovation in the textile industry.

search_results.description: Integrative medicine is a rapidly growing specialty field of medical care that emphasizes the amalgamation of complementary therapies and conventional medicine. Aromatherapy, one of the complementary therapies, is a centuries-old tradition, used in many cultures and societies as an alternative to, or in conjunction with, conventional medicine. However, there is very little understanding of its ...
snippets:
Aromatherapy in Textiles: A Systematic Review of Studies Examining Textiles as a Potential Carrier for the Therapeutic Effects of Essential Oils †
Abstract
:1. Introduction
1.1. Revival of Aromatherapy
1.2. Effect of Aromatic Compounds on Our Senses
2. Selection of Literature
- The study must have well-directed goals/objectives.
- Therapeutic effects of the fragrances were tested using a suitable experimental methodology.
- The study had a sample representative of sufficient subject population OR the sample studies were selected from credible database sources for review papers.
- Data were analyzed using appropriate statistical methods.
- The study was published in a peer-reviewed journal.
3. Mechanism for the Delivery of Aromatic Compounds
3.1. Encapsulation of Aromatic Compounds
3.2. Techniques and Examples of Microencapsulated EO on Textiles
3.3. Environmental Considerations
3.4. Use of Cyclodextrin and Aromatic Componds

3.5. Challenges and Opportunities in the Delivery of Aromatic Compounds
4. Medical Textiles
4.1. Bio-Functional Textiles
4.2. Biocidal Applications
4.3. Therapeutic Applications
5. Conclusions
- Studies in the area of aromatherapy are generally using the traditional application of essential oils via massage therapy to understand the therapeutic benefit of EOs. Upon topical application, EOs release their aroma with a burst, which quickly dissipates. There is no focus on optimizing the dosage, control of the EO release rate or the delivery mechanism. These studies are vexed with several issues and the results are rarely reproducible, which poses questions on their scientific worth.

- On the other hand, studies which focused on achieving the controlled release, EO concentration optimization, and delivery mechanism such as micro/nanoencapsulation for controlled release of aroma are focused truly on the encapsulation mechanism and not on assessing the “therapeutic” benefit of such aromatherapeutic textiles.
Funding
Institutional Review Board Statement
Informed Consent Statement
Data Availability Statement
Conflicts of Interest
